awd_titl_txt: Regulation of floral growth and patterning in Arabidopsis thaliana
awd_abstract_narration:
Beth Krizek
IOS-1354452
Regulation of floral growth and patterning in Arabidopsis thaliana

Flowers initiate from the shoot apical meristem, a dome-shaped structure at the top of a plant that produces new organs throughout the plant's life. After outgrowth of a flower primordium from the meristem, floral organ primordia appear in characteristic positions within the flower and develop into one of four organ types: sepals, petals, stamens or carpels. Little is known about the mechanisms that control the positioning of floral organ initiation at particular locations within the flower and the means by which floral organs grow and develop into their characteristic forms. The experiments proposed here will investigate these little-understood aspects of plant development by studying two proteins that have partially overlapping functions in regulating gene expression within a flower. This project will use molecular and genetic approaches to investigate whether these proteins interact with each other and genomic approaches to identify genes that are regulated by these proteins. These studies will provide novel insights into pathways controlling the initiation and development of floral organs. As flowers give rise to essential components of the human diet, an understanding of how a flower is formed will contribute knowledge important for agricultural improvements needed to feed a growing world population. The collaborative nature of the project will provide interdisciplinary research experiences for students and a postdoctoral fellow in plant development, genomics and bioinformatics. The project will also provide a summer research internship for a high school teacher who will use this experience to develop inquiry-based learning modules.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on understanding how floral organs (sepals, petals, stamens and carpels) attain their identity, size, and morphology. In the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, two proteins required for floral organ development are AINTEGUMENTA (ANT) and AINTEGUMENTA-LIKE6 (AIL6). ANT and AIL6 are related transcription factors that act by binding to the regulatory regions of genes to control which genes get expressed in different cells. Such control of gene expression is critical for organ development. ANT and AIL6 have partially overlapping functions as loss of both proteins has a more severe defect than loss of either one individually. While loss of AIL6 function on its own has no visible phenotype, loss of ANT function results only in smaller floral organs. In the absence of ANT and AIL6, flowers do not make petals, stamens, or carpels. Instead very small floral structures are formed that consist of sepals, filaments, and other abnormal organs.

Our work identified a number of genes that are regulatory targets of ANT and AIL6 providing important information about how ANT and AIL6 promote floral organ development. ANT and AIL6 directly bind to genes that specify petal, stamen, and carpel identity to promote these different floral organ fates. In addition, ANT and AIL6 contribute to the size and shape of floral organs by directly regulating genes that control organ growth and polarity. A second important finding from our work is that AIL6 regulates a subset of the genes regulated by ANT, thus explaining how AIL6 can provide some but not all of the functions of ANT. A third important finding of our work is that AIL6 can provide all of the functions of ANT when expressed at the same levels and spatial pattern as ANT. Thus, the differences between ANT and AIL6 primarily result from differences in the levels and places where these proteins are located within developing flowers.

Knowledge from this project has contributed to a better understanding of the gene regulatory networks by which floral organs adopt their identity and attain a characteristic size and appearance. As flowers give rise to seeds, grains, and fruits, our work may be translated to agriculturally important plants to increase crop yields. The project involved the training of graduate students and undergraduate students in plant molecular biology and developmental genetics. Furthermore, the Co-PI provided training of the PI in bioinformatics and genomics. In addition, the project provided a research experience for a high school teacher who developed inquiry-based learning modules for their classroom.
